conclusion: There are objects casting shadows (A, B, and C) on a surface, illuminated by a light source.
Shadows A, B, and C are initially cast to the left of the objects.
The light source moves to the right above the objects.
When the light source moves to the right, it changes the angle at which light hits the objects.
This shift in angle causes the direction of the shadows to change.
Shadows will now be cast to the opposite side, which means they will shift to the right of the objects.
The size of shadows is primarily influenced by the angle of the light source relative to the objects.

As the light source moves to the right, the shadows may become longer or shorter depending on the new angle, but typically, they will not change significantly in size unless the light source moves much higher or lower.

When the light source moves to the right above the objects, the shadows A, B, and C will shift to the right side of the objects. The size of the shadows may change slightly depending on the new angle, but the primary change will be in their position.
Shadows A, B, and C will shift to the right side of the objects when the light source moves to the right above them.
